Award.AwardTitle: RUI / LTREB -- Long-term Investigation of Territorial Behavior and Population Dynamics in the Common Loon
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on 95 territorial pairs of common loons, aquatic birds that breed on lakes across the northern U.S. and Canada. The research examines three chief topics: 1) fatal fighting among males for territories, 2) use of the 'yodel' call to defend territories, and 3) stability of a population that is threatened by shoreline development, recreational activity and the toxic effects of methylmercury. This study requires marking of loons with leg bands, observation from canoes, and simple experiments such as playbacks of territorial calls and placement of loon decoys.

This research project addresses scientific questions about animal behavior. One such question is 'Why do long lived species engage in lethal battles for territory when they have access to unused breeding space nearby?'. Because the investigator has a large sample of known-age birds in the study population, it will be possible to test several hypotheses to answer the question, including the hypothesis that fatal battlers are old residents with nothing to lose. Loons are very charismatic birds, and behavioral findings will be disseminated through popular articles, media coverage and educational websites for schoolchildren. An additional aim of the project - measurement of population stability and impacts of methylmercury - will determine whether state and federal agencies should study means to increase loon reproductive success and reduce emissions of mercury from industrial sources. The project extends a fruitful 15 year partnership between a small college and a major research university that trains 5 undergraduates annually in techniques required for field study of animals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed questions related to territorial behavior in the common loon (Gavia immer), a well-loved aquatic bird that breeds in pairs on lakes in the northern U. S. and Canada (Fig. 1). Both sexes of loons defend breeding positions from intruders, which attempt to usurp them from owners. Thus, territory defense and acquisition are highly important to loon reproductive success.

A first question addressed by the study concerned fatal battles for territories. About one-third of all male usurpations are fatal for the displaced breeder; females almost never fight to the death. Lethal battles of males are puzzling, because loons are long-lived, and territories are not in short supply. We tested three hypotheses for fatal?fighting: 1) that fatal battles constitute a “terminal investment” for old, declining males, 2) that males that fight to the death defend chicks well, which offsets their hyper?aggressiveness, or 3) that extreme familiarity with a territory causes fatal battles. Five years of investigation yielded partial support for the terminal investment hypothesis, revealed two syndromes (behaviors consistent within an individual) and rejected the “familiarity” hypothesis. We continue to work to complete testing of the terminal investment hypothesis.

Second, we examined hypotheses to explain calls given by male loons. The territorial call of males, termed the yodel, is complex in its acoustic structure and likely full of information (Fig. 2). We sought to determine whether the yodel of loons was a means of communicating: 1) identity, 2) body size, and/or 3) willingness to defend their territory. We found that, although each male’s yodel is unique, like a human voice, loons that hear the yodel seem not to use information regarding the identity of the yodeller. Instead, they respond to the pitch of the call, which is an indication of the yodeller’s size and fighting ability. In addition, yodellers appear to use the duration of the yodel to communicate their willingness to defend their territory aggressively.

A third goal of the study was to look at the stability of the loon population in northern Wisconsin. Since we systematically capture and mark (Fig. 3) adult loons and their chicks each year and make repeated efforts to relocate them, we were able to develop models to estimate adult survival rate, juvenile survival rate and overall population stability. We found that about 90% of all adults and 77% of all juveniles survive from one year to the next. However, survival of juveniles from small and acidic lakes was lower than from large and neutral-pH lakes. The population in northern Wisconsin appears to be stable.     

We made additional unanticipated findings in the course of our investigations. Loons settle on breeding lakes similar to their natal lakes in size and pH, a finding that is rare in ecology and has important implications for loon conservation. Loons also show a dramatic change in territory settlement behavior as they age: young loons (4-5 years) and very old loons settle on vacant lakes to breed; whereas loons that are 5-8 years of age fight with territory owners to usurp existing territories (Fig. 4). We also detected stark differences in social behavior between young nonbreeders that intrude into established territories and older birds.

In addition to its value to science, the project augmented the education of many young biologists.
